result.text:
I’m really confused about the new Codex limits.

I was working this morning and suddenly got locked out. I’ve never once hit a limit in a 5-hour window, and today I’ve only sent around 15 messages, all on low settings. Same story yesterday, only low-setting usage.

@thsottiaux @embirico could you please check what’s going on here?

The OpenAI website for Plus says:

Local tasks: Average users can send 30–150 messages every 5 hours with a weekly limit.

So how am I locked out for nearly a week when I’ve never even seen a warning before? I really don’t see how I could be hitting the limits.

@OpenAI

legacy.full_text:
👀

We are prioritizing improving how the Codex rate limit mechanism works to avoid hitting the issue where you use most of your weekly limit and then hit a 5 day wait period. We also plan to better surface how much is used and when you get close to the limit.

result.text:
Your RAG pipeline isn't performing well? 
The problem might not be your 𝘳𝘦𝘵𝘳𝘪𝘦𝘷𝘢𝘭 or 𝘨𝘦𝘯𝘦𝘳𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 - it's probably your data preparation.

Most people jump straight into building RAG systems without properly preparing their data. But here's the thing: 𝗴𝗮𝗿𝗯𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗶𝗻, 𝗴𝗮𝗿𝗯𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗼𝘂𝘁. Your RAG is only as good as the data you feed it.

But with these 6 advanced techniques that can take your RAG performance to the next level:

𝗗𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗣𝗿𝗲-𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴: Before anything else, clean your raw data. Remove formatting artifacts, standardize encodings, handle special characters. Your embedding model will thank you later.

𝗗𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗖𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴: Strip out the noise - navigation menus, footers, ads, duplicate content. Focus on what actually provides value to your users instead of confusing your retrieval system.

𝗗𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗘𝘅𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 & 𝗣𝗮𝗿𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴: Extract structured information from PDFs, HTML, and docs while preserving context. This isn't just getting text out - it's maintaining relationships between content sections.

𝗗𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: Normalize formats and enrich with metadata. Consistent structure helps your embedding model create better vector representations.

𝗟𝗟𝗠-𝗕𝗮𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝗖𝗵𝘂𝗻𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴: Instead of fixed-size chunks, use LLMs to identify natural breaking points based on semantic meaning. This creates chunks that actually make sense as standalone information pieces.

𝗟𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗖𝗵𝘂𝗻𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴: Delay chunking until after initial processing. This lets you make informed decisions about where to split content while preserving contextual information.

The chunking piece is especially critical. Too small chunks? Your LLM gets fragments like "In the dense areas, most of the concentration is via medium- and high-rise buildings" with zero context. Too large chunks? You hit context limits and include irrelevant information.

The sweet spot? Chunks that include enough context (like source, section titles, surrounding sentences) without overwhelming the model.

Simple chunking with fixed sizes and overlap is a good start, but semantic chunking that breaks text by meaning rather than character count is where the things get really good.

𝗗𝗼𝘄𝗻𝗹𝗼𝗮𝗱 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗔𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗱 𝗥𝗔𝗚 𝗧𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲𝘀 𝗴𝘂𝗶𝗱𝗲: https://t.co/fdzAYZX47p

MetaBuddy boosted their user engagement by 3x and cut trainer analysis time by 60% - using Weaviate’s Query Agent.

𝗕𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗶𝗿𝘀𝘁, 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗶𝘀 𝗠𝗲𝘁𝗮𝗕𝘂𝗱𝗱𝘆?
MetaBuddy is a platform that connects fitness enthusiasts through interactive wellness experiences, events, and personalized coaching. But like many fitness platforms, they hit a massive data problem.

𝗧𝗵𝗲𝗶𝗿 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗹𝗲𝗺:
Users' wellness data is trapped in separate systems: nutrition here, workouts there, sleep tracking somewhere else. Trainers drown in spreadsheets for hours just to answer one client's question.

𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗴𝗲𝗱: 
The Query Agent turned chaos into conversation.

NOW users simply ask: "Show my protein-heavy dinners under 600 kcal last week and how they affected recovery."
The Query Agent instantly translates natural language → complex queries → exact answers with sources.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗰𝘁 is real: 
✅ 3× more user engagement (people actually USE their data now)
✅ 60% less trainer analysis time
✅ One semantic interface replaced dozens of fixed filters
✅ Proactive coaching triggers based on real patterns

Why it works: The Query Agent eliminated custom query pipelines while building user trust through explainable results. Console-to-API parity meant rapid prototyping to production.

“Weaviate’s Query Agent allowed us to unify our users’ wellness data into a single intelligent interface. Our users love the natural language interactions, and our trainers now have a powerful tool to personalize coaching at scale.” — Waseem Sarwar, Product Lead at MetaBuddy

The future of wellness isn't more dashboards, it's intelligent conversation with YOUR data.

Want the full story? Read how MetaBuddy moved from siloed dashboards to conversational coaching:
https://t.co/R8mKLTzBNb

Special thanks to Waseem and Shoaib Abbasi for sharing their story 💚

legacy.description: Lead Engineer at @AIPRMcorp (https://t.co/fepyWfV4kA) and @lrt_co (https://t.co/p7LEvIKduG), building AIPRM for ChatGPT & Claude. Signal @ btibor.91

result.text:
Summary of AMA with the Codex Team on Reddit on 2025-09-17

Internal Usage & Team Workflow

- Team members use Codex to build Codex itself, with designers directly merging PRs and one engineer using it for 99% of their changes to Codex specifically, with goal of not typing single line of code by hand next year

- Product team members use Codex for languages they're not strong in like Rust, often starting tasks on mobile between meetings then using VS Code extension to pull down work

- Engineers prototype large features with ~5 turns of prompting to build multiple versions quickly and understand scope, using mix of CLI and VS Code extension to parallelize work and review code snippets in real time

- Team uses it for one-off internal tools, visualization, monitoring, training data generation, and designer splits time 70/30 between Codex and design tooling to reduce gap between idea and execution

Platform Availability & Technical Limitations

- Available through homebrew, npm, and direct binary downloads from GitHub releases, with plans to improve Windows support but no PyPi package available due to significant work required for every package manager

- Would love to support more IDEs like JetBrains but huge amount of work remains on core experience

- The team is shipping UI improvements but acknowledges terminal output readability issues, as different terminals render outputs differently - more improvements are coming

Usage Limits & Pricing Structure

- Product lacks UI to show approaching limits which team is working to improve

- Rate limits reset every 5 hours and weekly

- No free tier available and no current plans for mid-tier between Plus and Pro though many users request one

- Batch API-style usage for Codex web during unused GPU capacity discussed as great idea but not prioritized

Model Capabilities & Configuration

- GPT-5-Codex model is specifically optimized for coding tasks with focused training on diverse coding environments, making separate specialized models for frontend/backend potentially unnecessary since coding tasks span multiple domains

- Works well with large codebases using grep instead of dedicated indexing, can be prompted to work longer/faster and produce multi-page detailed implementation plans with different specification levels

- Codex web chooses best configuration for tasks without allowing model or reasoning selection

- GPT-5-high recommended for planning with more general world knowledge, GPT-5-Codex for technical refactors

- No plans to allow system prompt editing though users can modify AGENTS[.]md for coding-adjacent tasks like data analysis or non-coding tasks

Features & User Experience

- CLI supports web search with --search flag coming to IDE extension soon with prompt caching issues being resolved, potentially with full browser automation in the future

- VS Code extension supports drag & drop when holding shift key, has auto context feature and enables mixing local and cloud work

- File tagging with @ requested for folders not just individual files

- Voice mode for terminal/IDE interaction - team would find it very cool to provide native support after seeing exciting open source community demos hacking together voice and coding agents

- Can try local models with ollama using --oss flag though not first-class experience yet, with any future gpt-oss versions expected to work much better than current 20B model

Planning & Agent Development

- Currently has Chat/Plan mode in IDE extension and read-only mode in CLI, working on dedicated plan mode with team landing on giving users more control over execution rather than having model do its own planning

- Sub-agents are a fantastic way of preserving context for longer complex tasks but nothing actively being worked on right now

- Conversation compacting for longer work coming soon and users able to ask Codex to create plans in markdown files for review and editing, with ability to prompt for multi-page documents where model will work for extended periods

Integration & Workflow Improvements

- Team would love to build ChatGPT mobile app integration to trigger Codex agents from chat and enable conversation transfer between ChatGPT and Codex with UX still being worked out, plus MCP server integration for Codex web hopefully soon

- GPT-5-Codex Pro might be coming (responded to the question with eyes emoji)

Long-term Vision

- Team excited about world where non-coders build and deploy apps without touching IDE or terminal but Codex currently focused on professional software engineers rather than complete deployment handling

- Team hopes Codex becomes as ubiquitous as compilers fading into background, with abstraction level rising so engineers work at system level rather than code level where simple CRUD endpoints are nearly all written by Codex

- Engineers becoming more generalist with design and product skills enabling single engineers to own large product spaces, with potential for new programming languages designed to be less footgun-y for LLMs to use and Tony Stark/Jarvis collaboration model where humans talk to agent coworkers building individual parts while maintaining control over direction even if agents become smarter at programming

result.text:
For @bobvanluijt, building @weaviate_io wasn’t a choice...

That’s how founders need to feel:
“You will die if you don’t do it."

🎙️ I talked with Bob van Luijt, co-founder and CEO of Weaviate, the open-source vector database that's become core infrastructure for AI-native applications:

We talk about how Bob grew up in a small Dutch town, started coding in QBasic, and built his first software company while still in school. Then came the unexpected turn: jazz.

He shares how studying music (from a conservatory in the Netherlands to Berklee in Boston) taught him grit, deep focus, and how to think in systems. For Bob, writing code and playing music happen in the same part of the brain.

We talk about how Weaviate began as a side project fueled by curiosity about the distance between words, and how that simple idea turned into one of the most used vector databases in the world. Bob explains how the release of transformer models unlocked everything, and how he's stayed focused on helping real developers build, not just chasing hype.

We also get into his philosophy on building companies, how he thinks about talent and education, and why he believes too much "academic thinking" blocks real potential. Bob’s not in it for the ego or the exit... he’s building tools for other builders.

@builddeeptech #80
"You Will Die If You Don’t Do It"
with Bob van Luijt, co-founder and CEO of Weaviate

🎥 YouTube: https://t.co/skdfrnldl1

🎧 Spotify: https://t.co/5nbtM60jaN

🎧 Apple: https://t.co/ZcqssW6wiI

result.text:
We’re excited to announce:
The Weaviate Query Agent is now GA!

WQA is a Weaviate-native agent that transforms natural language questions into precise database operations, giving you reliable, fully transparent results.

It supports:
• Dynamic filters
• Smart routing across collections
• Aggregations
• Accurate results with full source citations

The result? Faster, more reliable, and fully transparent data-aware AI.

How to get started:
• 𝗜𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗼𝗹𝗲: Explore your data with natural language. See the Agent's "thought process" and the sources it used.
• 𝗩𝗶𝗮 𝗔𝗣𝗜𝘀/𝗦𝗗𝗞𝘀: Embed this intelligent querying directly into your applications, reducing boilerplate and shipping faster.

Key benefits:
• Say goodbye to custom query-rewriting pipelines.
• Get structured, predictable data back.
• Full transparency: see every filter, aggregation, and source.
• Automatically handles queries across multiple data collections and tenants.

Try it yourself:
🔬 Colab quickstart → https://t.co/Z7ZMDUVwTf
✍️ Launch blog → https://t.co/wJHrZ70Lca

result.text:
What makes a chatbot actually agentic?

One responds. The other reasons.

Most AI chatbots today are stuck in a simple loop: 
𝘁𝗲𝘅𝘁 𝗴𝗼𝗲𝘀 𝗶𝗻 → 𝘁𝗲𝘅𝘁 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘀 𝗼𝘂𝘁. 

But imagine a chatbot that can decide 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝗮𝘆, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗶𝘁.
A chatbot that learns from your preferences, reasons through complex data, and explains why it made each choice.

That’s "𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗰" 𝗔𝗜.

At its core, an AI agent is a system that uses an LLM as its brain to 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘀𝗼𝗹𝘃𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲𝘅 𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝘀.

Think of 𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀 as automated decision-making engines: you bring the query, they figure out how to solve it using whatever is available.

𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗔𝗜 𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗰?

• It can reason about problems and break them into steps
• It has access to tools and knows when to use them
• It maintains memory of past interactions
• It can adapt its approach based on what's working

𝗧𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗔𝗜 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗚𝗹𝗼𝘄𝗲

We recently tested this by powering 𝗚𝗹𝗼𝘄𝗲'𝘀 𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗰𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝘁𝗯𝗼𝘁 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩 𝗘𝗹𝘆𝘀𝗶𝗮, our open-source agentic RAG framework.

𝗘𝗹𝘆𝘀𝗶𝗮‘𝘀 𝟯 𝗸𝗲𝘆 𝗳𝗲𝗮𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝘀:

1️⃣ Decision trees that think out loud: Unlike black-box systems, Elysia uses a transparent decision tree where each node is orchestrated by an agent that explains its reasoning. You can literally watch it think through problems step by step.

2️⃣ Dynamic display intelligence: While other assistants are limited to text responses, Elysia can choose from seven different display formats - tables, product cards, conversations, documents, charts, and more. It analyzes your data structure and picks the most appropriate way to present information.

3️⃣ Automatic data expertise: Before answering any query, Elysia studies your entire dataset - understanding structures, relationships, and context. No more blind vector searches hoping for relevant results.

𝗧𝗼𝗼𝗹𝘀 𝘄𝗲 𝗯𝘂𝗶𝗹𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗚𝗹𝗼𝘄𝗲 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗼𝗳 𝗘𝗹𝘆𝘀𝗶𝗮:

• 𝗪𝗲𝗮𝘃𝗶𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗤𝘂𝗲𝗿𝘆 𝗔𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁 for complex product filtering
• A stack generator that creates personalized product collections through natural language
• A recommendations engine based on user context

Elysia came built-in with all the complex agentic behaviors: recursion, self-healing, error handling, streaming, allowing us to focus entirely on skincare-specific logic.

Try Elysia yourself:

🔗 GitHub: https://t.co/whMh3cs3jZ
📖 Demo: https://t.co/faD5mleHpi
🎮 Blog post: https://t.co/TiBHepQKMY

Me and @0xkkonrad hacked together a quick mini extension to highlight AI slop online. It works super well on Twitter. This tweet by @iamtrask, for example: CLEARLY AI generated (or aided).

Wrong.

And I'm pretty annoyed at this recent trend to assume anyone using typographic marks must be using AI. On Mac, opt-shift-hyphen is em-dash, and is really handy. Ditto for opt-space creating non-breaking space. Also copying from a web page using &nbsp; will give the same.
Also anyone (like me) using Chinese/Japanese input will often accidentally use an idiographic space due to forgetting to switch input methods, or just from copy/paste.
RT @deanwball: I think Demis is fundamentally correct here. The current systems are extremely impressive, and will get much more so soon, b…

legacy.description: Senior Fellow at @joinfai | Author of Hyperdimensional

result.text:
I think Demis is fundamentally correct here. The current systems are extremely impressive, and will get much more so soon, but it’s clear there are fundamental breakthroughs still needed.

As I have written before, I expect us to get “superintelligence” (AI systems that can, say, autonomously advance the frontiers of math and physics) before we get “AGI.” AI systems will make novel contributions to group theory well before they can autonomously plan a wedding. 

Yet that’s no reason to be bearish on near-term AI. Indeed, in my view it’s one of the better imaginable scenarios. Here’s one way the near future could play out: 

1. Significant productivity gains—first in software engineering, then cascading to other fields.
2. Increasing institutional comfort with AI and automation; as a civilization, we will have time (not a ton of time, but a period measured in years rather than months) to develop legal, financial, conceptual, and other infrastructural technologies that allow us to adapt to AI more effectively. 
3. A mathematical and scientific renaissance, which itself will create new ideas and wealth. 

And with these, we go into the “real AGI” phase equipped with more wealth, more effective ideas and abstractions, more sophisticated knowledge of using AI, and better-prepared institutions than we have today. 

Perhaps I am naive, but I suspect we have been dealt a pretty good hand.

legacy.description: @Stripe CEO, @ArcInstitute cofounder.

result.text:
Observing some people close to me with chronic health conditions, it's striking how useful Reddit frequently ends up being. I think a core reason is because trials aren’t run for a lot of things, and Reddit provides a kind of emergent intelligence that sits between that which any single physician can marshal and the full rigor of clinical trials.

Why aren’t trials run for a lot of things? Well, they’re of course slow and expensive (median cost of $19M for a pivotal trial in 2015[1]; after adjusting for inflation and other phases, maybe that corresponds to a total of $40M today?). But they’re also hard to fund when the intervention in question lacks IP protection since the ensuing knowledge can’t be monetized. As such, trials for diet, over-the-counter supplements, and lifestyle interventions are under-pursued. To give one prosaic example, lots of people think that magnesium improves sleep, but, as far as I know, no trial has ever been run assessing its ability to improve sleep in non-elderly adults without sleep disorders.

So, Reddit — in a pretty unstructured way — makes a limited kind of “compounding knowledge” possible. Best practices can be noticed and can imperfectly start to accumulate. For people with chronic health problems, this is a big deal, and I’ve heard lots of stories between “I found something that made my condition much more manageable” all the way to “I found a permanent cure in a weird comment buried deep in a thread”. (Of course, one also sees this outside of medical conditions. I’ve enjoyed the recommended routine in the BodyWeightFitness subreddit, as a comparable kind of distilled practical wisdom[2].)

An interesting and somewhat more formalized example of this approach was recently used for long COVID and published earlier this year[3]. After surveying 3,900 individuals, the paper analyzes patient-reported outcomes for 150 different treatments, yielding the figure reproduced below. There are evidently no silver bullets, but it is striking that, say, about half of people find that antihistamines are helpful. I know a number of people who found the learnings from this study to be impactful in improving their daily quality-of-life.

Seeing this paper and the Reddit experience makes me wonder whether the approach could somehow be scaled: is there a kind of observational, self-reported clinical trial that could sit between Reddit and these manual approaches? Should there be a platform that covers all major chronic conditions, administers ongoing surveys, and tracks longitudinal outcomes?

I don’t really know what the best way to go about this would be, but it feels to me that there could be something important here. There’s a lot of latent data in patients’ subjective experiences that is not today being properly gathered or analyzed.

result.text:
Google does NOT get a rehearing of its appellate loss to Epic Games, neither by the 3-judge panel nor by an enlarged panel ("en banc"). Not a single 9th Circuit judge requested a vote on Google's petition.

Now Google has only one last chance: the Supreme Court. Otherwise Google must comply with the injunction. The motion for a stay pending a Supreme Court petition was denied. The 9th Circuit just extended some compliance deadlines, but only gradually so. Google will now presumably ask the Supreme Court for emergency intervention.
